DIV1.P: AS IT IS NOW PERFORMING AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: Printed for FIELDING and WALKER, Paternoster-Row; J. DODSLEY, Pall-Mall; T. BECKET, Strand; and T. DAVIES, Russel-Street, Covent-Garden.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE favourable reception which the fol∣lowing Comedy has met with from a candid and generous Public, calls for my warmest acknowledgements; and tho' it may be of little consequence to them to know the source of so slight an amusement, I think myself bound by truth and gratitude to own, that the first idea of this Piece was hinted to me by my ever-respected and lamented friend Mr. GARRICK, who mentioned GOLDONI's Bourru Bienfaisant, as a sketch that, if adapted to our times and manners, might be rendered pleasing to an English Audience. Those who have read the French Piece must judge how far I have profited by GOLDONI's work; but of this I am certain, that had Mr. GARRICK lived to afford me that friendly assistance which he has done on former occasions, my Comedy would have been more worthy of the reception with which it has been honoured. I will, however, hope that, with all its imperfec∣tions on its head, the same indulgence which attended its representation, will follow it into the closet; and that the Reader will allow me the only merit I presume to claim, that of meaning well.

I gladly take this opportunity of returning my thanks to my much-esteemed friend, Mr. SHERIDAN, senior, for his kind attention to the getting up my Play, my ill health not permitting me to attend one Rehearsal. But Mr. SHERIDAN's friendship, wherever pro∣fessed, is not of modern growth.

I have more than common acknowledge∣ments to make to all the Performers in my Comedy; particularly to Mrs. ABINGTON and Miss POPE, who both chearfully undertook Parts out of their usual line of acting, and in which they have both excelled. I should be utterly unable to express my sentiments of Mr. KING, in the character of SIR WILLIAM WOODLEY, if I were not at liberty seriously to adopt the very words which he humorously, but justly, speaks of himself, under a personated character, in The Critic:—But it is impossible for language to do justice to Mr. KING! Indeed, he more than merited those repeated bursts of applause which he drew from a most bril∣liant and judicious Audience.

I flatter myself, this little tribute to distin∣guished merit will not be deemed tedious or impertinent by the Public, for whose opinion I have the sincerest respect, and to whom I have the honour to be

CLOSER.SIGNED: A much obliged, And most obedient Servant, THE AUTHOR.

LG.L: TO glow with ardour, and attempt with zeal
The reformation of the public weal,
Is the high duty of the COMIC MUSE;
And tho' keen Attic Salt allowed to use,
To season Precept, and with Art to tickle
The sores she means to wash with sharpest pickle,
Yet not the rosy, pulpited Divine,
Nor lank-hair'd Methodist with rueful whine,
Is more intent to root out Vice and Folly,
And make ye all lead lives discreet and holy.—
Yet why to clear the field were all their toil,
If weeds o'erspread not the luxuriant soil?
Congreve or Wesley, Whitfield or Moliere,
In vain might prompt the laugh, or bribe the tear,
If no man felt, or in himself, or neighbour,
Some failing to call forth the zealot's labour;—
If no fair dame descried, 'midst her acquaintance,
Some few who might be mended by repentance.
Loose as the buxom air, the Youth from College
Comes fraught with all Newmarket's hopeful knowledge;
In haste to spend the Estate, not yet his own,
Compleats his ruin ere his beard is grown;
And when to foreign climes he spreads the sail,
'Tis not to enlarge his mind, but 'scape a jail.
Then blest the Poet, happy the Divine,
When Folly gives the Ton from Fashion's Shrine!
But whilst the Priest and Satirist reprove
Those vices which provoke the wrath of JOVE,
Our Author, like the patient Angler sitting
To catch small fry, for humbler palates sitting,
Has served a Meal, not seasoned high with crimes.—
Taste it, and if approved, applaud THE TIMES.
WHILE grave-paced Tragedy, with Oh's! and Starts!
Flies at high game, to move and mend your hearts,
We merrier folks, with spirits blithe and jolly,
Just perch upon some little sprig of folly:
For, in this Age, so pious, chaste, and grave,
To rail at Vice, must surely be to rave!
Yet thanks to here and there a modish fool,
The COMIC MUSE may glean some ridicule.
Jews will be Jews, if dupes can yet be found,
And if one frail one's left on English ground,
She'll find a Phaeton and pair of ponies
To elope—for all men are not Maccaronies:—
Those precious Dears, at least, would make her wait—
'Twould be so vulgar, not to be too late.
Our sex—but shall I charge the weaker kind?
Or can those fail to stray, whose guides are blind!
Let men reform themselves, they're our examples—
And goods prove seldom better than their samples.
In former times the gallant British Youth
Were formed for Chivalry, and Love, and Truth—
In such an Age, in such a virtuous Nation,
Love was in woman almost inspiration.—
But now, alas! I speak without a jest,
Women are not inspired—they're but possest.
Men are our pilots! They should mark the shelves;
For when they blame us, they reproach themselves.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, A Dressing-room, Books, Music, Clothes scattered about.
Mr. WOODLEY dressing, FORWARD at a distance.
DIV2.P: SURE, never man was so suddenly involved as I have been!—and yet I cannot charge either my wife or myself with any particular extravagance. We do but live like other people of our rank; and yet, in less than four years that we have been mar∣ried, an estate of four thousand pounds a-year has dwindled into nothing!—Heigh-ho!— (observing Forward listening, he hums a tune)—I can neither get this Air into my head, or out of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: I am often plagued so, myself, Sir, after the first night of a new Opera, tho' I have a to∣lerable ear, and catch a tune pretty readily.
SP.STAGE: Enter a Footman, and delivers a Letter to Mr. Woodley. He reads it, and appears agitated.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: What a proposal!—I would die first. Get me pen, ink, and paper

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: I'll fetch them instantly from the Library, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: You need not. I'll write there.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P:
He seems devilishly flurried by that same letter. I wish I could come fairly at its con∣tents. 'Tis no billet-doux, I am certain; for I have never found him tripping that way, since I have been in the family. It must be some matter of bu∣siness, and if it is, it may concern me as well as my master. I have had my doubts that our affairs were going wrong, for some months past. Our hall has been crowded with sturdy Tradesmen, and we have had sneaking Jews closeted in the Library.—Egad, I'll venture; for where interest is concerned, even my honour must give way— (takes up the letter). He may surprise me, tho'.—I wish his shoes creaked (looks out and listens).—No—all's safe yet; and now for the indulgence of a reasonable curiosity.— (reads.)
I find it impossible to trifle any longer with your creditors; the executions will therefore immedi∣ately be laid on, unless you can prevail on Lady Mary to release her jointure; for there is not even a Jew in Duke's-Place that will advance a guinea more on your estate, whilst that incumbrance re∣mains. I am your humble servant, JOHN FLEECE'EM.
P. S. I have scarce cash enough in my hands to discharge the inclosed small bill of costs.
Here's a bill, as long as his Taylor's!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P:
Puppy! What are you meddling with
those papers for? Give this letter to James, and order him to carry it instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Must I not put the things to rights, first, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Do as I order you, and leave the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Ay, and the place, too, as soon as your Honour can provide yourself. (aside.) I should not chuse to depend upon a post obit for my wages.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: How shall I be able to reveal my situa∣tion to Lady Mary! My heart bleeds for what she must suffer!

SP.SPEAKER: Footman.
SP.P: Colonel Mountfort, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Desire him to walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Good-morrow, Woodley! What, not dressed yet! I expected to find you booted, and ready to set out for Newmarket. You'll be late on the turf. Your horses run, I suppose? What matches have you made?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: None, Colonel. I shall not be there, this Meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You amaze me.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Would I had never been there! I am sick of the diversion, and shall never make another bett on the turf while I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Why don't you dispose of your stud, then? It must be an enormous, and now an useless expence.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Horses are the least part of the extrava∣gances incident to racing.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That is selon, Woodley; for I have known several fortunes made on the turf.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: True—but by those only who had none to lose. They are surest to win, who carry least weight.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Take my advice, then, and sell your horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Why, faith, I wish they were disposed of. But yet, I don't know, I should be ashamed, I think, to advertise them, as it might look some-how as if one could not afford to keep them. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Ridiculous supposition!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Ridiculous, indeed! That you know, Mountfort, is far from the case, but I really am tired of the sport; and the Meeting, too, is at a time of the year when there are so many more agreeable amusements to be met with in London, so that I should be glad to get rid of them, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Let me dispose of them for you, then. I'll be your Auctioneer, and try if I can't emblazon their pedigree with a little of that true humour which Charles Surface bestows on his ancestors, when he sets up their pictures to sale. Bucephalus, the fa∣mous Bucephalus, Gentlemen, descended in a right line from the renowned quadrupede of that name, which had the honour of carrying a greater brute than himself—the immortal Alexander—

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Bravo! Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Or shall we deduce his lineage from—

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: You had better consult Tattersall, for their pedigree, as he is your only herald in those points. Heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Heigh-ho! This is but poor encourage∣ment for me to enter on my new profession. Surely there is something malignant in the air, at present; for every man I have conversed with, this morning, seems rather to be depressed with the gloom of November, than enlivened by the sunshine of April. I have just now left Jack Knightly and Will Careless calculating, not their nativities, but their deaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I saw them both at Boodle's, yesterday, in good health.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P:
Not the more likely to live, for that, I as∣sure you. However, it was not their natural exist∣ence,
but their necessary subsistence, that employed their mathematics.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Woodley.
SP.P: You astonish me!—Why, it is but lately they came into possession of great estates.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: True:—but then they have travelled the modern short and easy road to ruin, of granting annuities for this twelvemonth past, and are now so nearly arrived at the last stage of their journey, that I think Jack said he had but two months to run; and Will flattered himself, that as the summer was approaching, he might be able to hold out four. I advised their compounding the terms, and run∣ning together for three months each.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Poor fellows! I am sorry for them. (aside.) Would I could promise myself even so long a reprieve.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What! moping again, Woodley? You'll infect me, if I stay.—Where are the Ladies?—In truth, my visit was to them, for I scarce hoped to find you here. Are Lady Mary and your sister visible? or shall I pass on to your Uncle's apartment, and pay my respects to him? I think there is a door of communication to his house from this room. Shall I go this way?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: That may be a service of danger, Colonel; for I fear Sir William is not at present much delighted either with his vicinity, or affinity, to any of this family, except my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I am glad to hear you can except my sweet Louisa; for, notwithstanding the brusqueness of his manners, I have such an opinion of the old Knight's good sense and good nature, that I cannot readily acquit those he is offended with, as wholly free from blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P:
I subscribe to your censure, as far as it relates to myself; but the asperity of his behaviour to Lady Mary, renders me extremely unhappy; and not even my past obligations, or future prospects,
shall ever make me acquiesce in his treating my wife with disrespect.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Allow me to say, Woodley, that persons so nearly connected, ought to dispense with ceremony, in favour of sincerity.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: That's a dangerous tenet, Colonel, and may be extended 'till downright rudeness may be considered but as the privilege of family-chat.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I think you have no cause for such an appre∣hension, in this case, as Sir William is quite as singular for goodness of heart, as for a deficiency in that outward varnish which too often supplies the place of it. But to compound the argument, let us admit there may be faults on both sides.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: My dear Woodley, don't I look like a hag, to-day? Do you know that I have not slept an hour, the whole night!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I'm sorry for it, my dear:—I hope it was not any illness that prevented your rest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: No—I was not the least ill; but the uncommon brilliancy of Lady Mushroom's ear-rings, that I saw at the Opera, in the evening, twinkled all night before my eyes, and would not suffer me to close them.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Vanity has her vigils, I perceive, Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: That's but fair, Colonel, as her festivals seem to bestow such supreme delight on her votaries of both sexes.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I think, now, that a thousand pounds added to my own, would make them out-blaze Lady Mushroom's; and I am sure my dear Woodley won't refuse me such a trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I can refuse you nothing—but we'll talk of it some other time.
SP.STAGE: Enter a Servant and delivers a Letter to Mr. Woodley, which he just runs his eye over, and puts up.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: What makes you look so grave, my Love? I should almost suppose that letter was from your Uncle, if he did not live in the same house, and had not a peculiar delight in seeing the effect of his own ill temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: The reprehensions of sincere friends pro∣ceed oftener from kindness, than ill-nature.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Will you send for Set∣well to-morrow, my Dear, if you are not at leisure to-day? I must have this bar taken out, the middle stone larger, and the drop at least twice this size: and pray hurry him, for I must positively wear them at Court, next Sunday.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: It must be so.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You don't attend to me, Mr. Woodley?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: O, yes, my Dear, I hear every word you say. Give me the ear-rings, I'll carry them myself to the Jeweller.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Here they are;—but don't be too extravagant:—I would not have more than a thousand pounds added, on any account.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I give you credit for that last caution, Lady Mary; as 'tis uncommon to hear a wife re∣straining her husband's generosity to herself, in this day.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: His indulgence, Colonel, has ever exceeded my wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: But never equalled my own. (aside.) My heart is breaking for her.
SP.STAGE: Enter a Servant, who gives a printed Paper to Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: With Mrs. Bromley's compliments, Madam, and requests you'll do her the honour to call on her.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: O! 'tis the Catalogue she promised to mark for me. My compliments, and I shall be at her door in a few minutes.—Louisa, are you dis∣posed for Christe's Rooms, this morning? There are abundance of fine things, and, of course, fine people, to be there. I delight in an Auction, one meets with so many things there, one never thought one wanted before.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Though it is not my passion, I'll attend your Ladyship with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: See, Wood∣ley, what an unconscionable creature Bromley is! She has marked a whole side of the Catalogue.—A lustre that holds a hundred lights! I think I should like that, now, for our grand saloon, in the country. I own, I should delight vastly to astonish our neigh∣bours in Dorsetshire—if ever we go there. Have you any objection, my Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: But one, my Dear—I am to settle with my Banker, to day.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: No matter—Mrs. Bromley shall be my Banker. Her purse is always at the service of her friends.—O, here's the sweetest sett of fillagree dressing-plate!—I must have that, Woodley, instead of the one I have had these two years.—'Tis abso∣lutely Gothic.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I cannot wound her by restraint.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Don't you think Mrs. Bromley a de∣lightful creature, Colonel?—Two of the largest Seve vases that have ever been imported. I po∣sitively must have them. How good it was in the dear Bromley to note these articles!—Why don't you tell me how you like my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I have not the honour, Madam, of knowing her sufficiently to judge of her character, and there∣fore can only speak of it as doubtful.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Doubtful, Colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: In some cases, Lady Mary, to doubt, is rather to compliment, than to censure.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: And, in other cases, to doubt, is to be cer∣tain.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You don't affect to be doubtful, I hope, Miss Woodley?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: By no means, I assure you. Mrs. Brom∣ley's character is quite clear to me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: If you talk in this stile, Louisa, I shall certainly conclude that you are jealous of the dear Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I know not on what account I should be so, except in your good graces; for I hope you don't think me vain enough to attempt rivalling her with her present Cecisbeo, Sir Harry Granger.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That ridiculous compound of affectation and epicurism! who ruminates upon every meal, and tries to preserve the relish of his sauces, by a repetition of their ingredients in every new com∣pany that admits him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You are monstrously censorious, Colo∣nel; but I will allow that he is a little out of fashion, at present; and for that reason, I have forbidden his ever coming into this house. The Bromleys dine here to-day, my Dear (to Mr. Woodley.)—But we lose time. The Auction may begin, and some of the dear things I have set my heart upon be gone before we get there.—I shall never forget that old frightful Mandarin, Lord Gobble, for whipping up the Seve China Dejeuner from me, at the last sale.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Will your Ladyship permit me to have the honour of attending you?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: There's a vacant seat in the coach, and you shall be welcome, if you won't be spiteful. Good morrow, Woodley! Come, Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P:
So—I am once more left at leisure for my own reflection. Solitude is said to be a relief to the unhappy; but thought only serves to double my distress. Surely my poverty begins to be appa∣rent,
or Knightly would not write so pressingly.—His note surprises me. (Reads)
Dear Woodley, I desire you will, on receipt of this, let me have the three hundred pieces you lost to me at our last Meeting, as I am just setting off for Newmarket, and must have some weight of metal to balance the scales on the turf. I shall wait at home for you exactly one hour, by the best going watch in Eu∣rope, and must have the cash by that time, pos. Yours ever, T. KNIGHTLY.

The peremptory stile of this billet alarms me! Knightly used to be a careless, liberal fellow; but Mountfort told me just now, that he is on the verge of ruin. His state, however, is to be envied, in com∣parison of mine. He falls alone. No wife, no family, at once to share and aggravate his wretched∣ness. I'll go this moment and acquit me of his de∣mand, by parting with these toys— (takes up the ear-rings). How much my Mary's beauty added to their lustre! Let me fly from the thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: Just on the wing, my dear friend! How lucky thus to catch you flying, as it were!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: The good fortune is rather mine, Mr. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: No, no; you compliment.—But where are the dear, the divine Ladies?—Mayn't I hope to be cheared with one glance from their bright eyes?—What a beautiful creature is Lady Mary!—Do you know she wants but little, very little, my dear friend, to be the top of the tree, the very para∣gon of fine taste and bon ton; and I think she will very soon acquire that little. My Dame has an ex∣cellent hand at touching up the last polish.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I allow Mrs. Bromley to be perfectly elegant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: No, no; there you are wrong.—She is pretty, lively, and so forth, but somewhat subsy, you know.—But Lady Mary, Lady Mary is the thing!—But what's here? (taking up the ear-rings)—A new purchase, I presume? They are fine, very fine, indeed! What now may the value be?—Some thousands, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: They did cost a pretty large sum, when they were bought.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: Not new, then, I perceive—but fine, very fine, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Lady Mary don't quite like the fashion—the setting, I mean;—and therefore I should not be sorry to part with them—and buy others.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: O, that alters the case considerably! Let us see—let's see. Why now, upon examining them closely, they appear but middling, very mid∣dling, indeed. I don't wonder Lady Mary should not like them—no lustre—very old fashion'd—they'll sell for little or nothing, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: They cost me fifteen hundred pounds, about four years ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: Fifteen hundred pounds!—You amaze me!—You must have been sadly imposed upon! very sadly, indeed, my dear friend! What monstrous cheats these tradesfolks are!—Why, these jewels, now, will not bring above three hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: That's more than the common dispro∣portion between buying and selling, I should think, Mr. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P:
I mean in the Trade, Mr. Woodley. Among the Trade, diamonds are a drug, a mere drug, indeed: and money is a rare jewel in all trades now, I'll assure you. A Gentleman, or a friend, per∣haps, might give more. Come, for the frolic's sake, I'll turn jeweller myself, and offer you a cool five
hundred for them. What say you? Is it a bargain, Woodley?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I cannot bear the thought of carrying them abroad to sell!—Well, if you really think they are worth no more—

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: Nay, I have over-rated them; but I never compute by pounds, shillings, and pence, when dealing with a friend. Diamonds are, as I told you before, a mere drug; and cash, cash, my dear boy, your only valuable commodity. Here, here it is (looking in his pocket-book).—I have not quite so much about me, I find.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: That's unlucky (looking at his watch); for I want three hundred of it, this very instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: Does the wind sit in that point?—I'll see—I'll see. O! here is just the three hundred, cut and dry, my boy. You shall have the other two this evening at Boodle's. We'll cut a card, or throw a cast for it, or how you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I shan't go to Boodle's to-night—nor do I think I shall ever play again.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: The knowing-ones are taken in. I would not have given so much for the jewels, if I had thought so.—What, not play? That's good, very good, indeed! You have a sort of lover's quarrel to the dice, I perceive. But though they have, I confess, used you a little scurvily, they'll make you amends some other time. One lucky hit, you know, may repay all your losses.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: They have so often, and so fatally de∣ceived me—

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: That you'll trust them again, for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I think not. But we shall meet at dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P:
Yes, yes; I obey the dear, sweet Lady Mary's invitation. I shall bring the money with me. Besides, I recollect, that you and I have a little
matter of business to settle; but it shan't break in upon our pleasures, tho'. You shall have no trouble but just to set your name. A memorandum is all I want, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I have a particular reason for desiring that you will not mention the transaction of the jewels to my wife, or even to yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bromley.
SP.P: Secret—secret as the grave, my dear friend—trusty as steel, my boy. You may always depend upon honest Bob Bromley. We shall be with you at five, tho' that's rather early (going).—Nay, no ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I am going out this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: I have listened and pryed to good purpose, I think, and am thoroughly confirmed in my resolution of shifting my quarters, to-morrow morning. Up tents, and away, then! But I cannot help being a little concerned at leaving my master and Lady; because I am sure I shall never get so good a place again. All masters—no servants—every one did as he liked. It grieves me to think what a hand the rest of the servants have made of them. There's the lazy Housekeeper, the drunken Butler, the cribbing Coachman!—But what signifies moralizing! Let me look about me a little, and see if there be any small matters lying loose, that are of no farther use to my master, and may be of some to me.— (Takes up a pair of lace ruffles) These have been worn, but never washed, and he may miss them. No, that's not probable, as he has at least twenty pair more than he knows any thing of— (puts them in his pocket). This snuff-box, too, is but a bauble, of more curiosity than value: I shall accept of it as a keep-sake— (pockets it).
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir William, from the middle door.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: By the quietness in the nest, the birds are flown; and I am glad of it. My apartment smokes a little, to-day. I'll have the tables brought here, and try if the game be recoverable: tho', to be sure, I have but little hopes; for sure there never was any man so unlucky.—Waters!

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: What! is old Square-Toes ruined, too? Egad, I should be glad of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: —Why, hey, what are you doing here?—Waters! I say—

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Only removing a few useless things of my master's, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Then you will certainly remove your∣self; for I know nothing half so useless, as a pert, coxcomical, lazy Valet-de-Chambre.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: As your Honour chuses to be alone, I shall retire directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Retire! There's a phrase now for a foot∣man! But these puppies all mimic their masters, even in their language, and what's worse, in their vices. I'll answer for it that fellow now, is as idle, as dissipat∣ed, and extravagant, as my nephew himself. But why do I think of a man whose misconduct has so totally alienated my affections? Yet he was a sweet boy at Eton, and a fine youth at College. His in∣discreet marriage has ruined him—a fine Lady—a Lady of Quality, forsooth, and without a fortune to support her vanity. But, no matter now—I re∣nounce them both.—Waters!—I wish Louisa was removed from this scene of folly and extravagance, and safely settled in the country. There is no other place for a woman to be secure in.
I wish you would advance, Mr. Slow-boots. I have called you at least a dozen times.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: I came the very moment—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, well, well—apologies take up time.—Bring the back-gammon tables here, then go to Counsellor Belford, and desire him to come to me, directly.— (Waters going through the middle door)—Why don't you go the shortest way?

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: Your Honour bid me bring the tables, first.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Of what use are they, when Belford is not here to play?— (Waters going)—No, come back, and fetch the tables, and I'll place the men just to shew you how I was gammoned, and I think you'll allow there never was such luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: I am utterly ignorant of every point of the game, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Stupidity in the abstract! How often have you been in the room, while Belford and I have been playing! Had we been saying or doing any thing we ought not, you would have picked it up fast enough, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No words—I hate prate—fly to Mr. Belford's— [Exit Waters]—I'll go and shew Jones how it was; for tho' she is my Housekeeper, now, she is a Parson's daughter, and must understand back∣gammon. I am sure she will be astonished at Bel∣ford's move.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter, at opposite doors, Mr. WOODLEY, and Mr. BELFORD.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: HOW truly do I rejoice to see my good friend Mr. Belford! But may I flat∣ter myself that the honour of this visit was intended for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I am sorry, my dear Sir, that there should be a necessity for discriminating the person to whom my respects are paid, in a family I so equal∣ly regard, and which was once so happily united.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: If indeed you regard this family, or ever had any friendship for me—But I cannot speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I am already apprized of your difficul∣ties, and would spare you the pain of even hinting at them, were it in my power to redress them.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Then be assured it is; for amidst all my distresses, nothing afflicts me half so much as Sir William's implacable resentment against Lady Mary and me. If he were but reconciled—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: That is, in plain English, my young friend, if he could be reconciled to your expensive mode of living, he ought in honour to assist in sup∣porting it. But that, I doubt, will never be brought to pass, though Sir William is both rich and ge∣nerous—

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: To all the world, but me.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P:
In this case, then, you should suspect your own conduct, rather than his character.—But remonstrances are useless, now; and I promise to use my utmost interest to bring about a reconciliation.
But I much fear that we shall not be able to get Lady Mary included in the family-compact; for I know no man more resolute in what he conceives to be right, than Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: My honour, as well as my love, obliges me to vindicate her; and I here pledge them both, that she is free from blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I am glad to find you still a lover, Mr. Woodley; but I who am but a friend, in this ques∣tion, can't help thinking, that if Lady Mary had spent more of her time in Dorsetshire, and less at Spa, Paris, and other places of dissipation and ex∣travagance, she would have been more entitled to Sir William's esteem, and you would have had less need of his assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: The fault was mine alone.—Vain of pos∣sessing such a treasure—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: You childishly exposed it to the gaze of fops and foreigners.—And let me tell you, Mr. Woodley, you are a lucky man, in these licentious times, to have preserved such a gem pure and entire, even at the expence of your other possessions. But, prithee, why don't you now retreat into the country?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: My wife is quite ignorant of my pre∣sent circumstances—I have not resolution to ac∣quaint her with them—and to propose quitting London, in this gay season, without assigning some cause—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Would, in your situation, be extremely prudent.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I cannot bear the thought of giving her uneasiness—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: And so cruelly prefer the evil to the cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P:
I humbly beg your Honour's pardon for my intrusion, but I have been at your Chambers,
and at the Temple Coffee-house, to look for you. My master is quite impatient to see you, Sir, and one of Mr. Woodley's servants told me you were here.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: This seems to fall out luckily. I will not detain you a moment. Dear Belford, remember what a cause you have in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Do not distrust my attention to my client, tho' I cannot warrant success to the suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: I cannot tell your Honour how proud I am to meet you. My good, dear master has been as angry with me for not finding you at home, as if I had committed the greatest of faults; and I would die rather than vex him.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I know my friend's hasty temper, per∣fectly well; but I also know that his good-nature is an over-match for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: O, Sir! you don't know how good and generous he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: You are mistaken, Waters; I am no stranger to Sir William's benevolence.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, with submission you are;—for he takes as much pains to conceal his goodness, as others do to reveal theirs. He would never for∣give me if he knew I mentioned it; but my heart is so glad, I can't help telling your Honour that he apprenticed my eldest boy, last week, and pays for the schooling of the two youngest.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: These are noble bounties, I confess, Waters; but I think your feelings on the occasion do as much honour to human nature, as the Knight's generosity;—for a liberal hand is more frequently to be met with, than a grateful heart.—But where is Sir William?

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P:
I left him going to take a turn in the garden, and I don't in the least doubt but he will come in as cool as a cucumber, tho' when he went
down stairs he was as angry with me, as if he had never done me any good.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Shew me the way, and I'll go to him directly.
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to a Dressing-Room, an elegant Toilet.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: They are pretty, I confess; but even I think them rather dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: What an idea for my dear Lady Mary! Do you know, now, that the equipage of Mrs. Stockwell's toilet, the Broker's wife, cost thirteen hundred pounds?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I remember her at Paris—an over∣dressed Thing!—I thought she had been a Jeweller's wife, and looked upon her as a stalking shew-glass, to expose her husband's goods for sale. But the poor man, I suppose, was ruined by her extravagance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he was done-up, very soon after. But the woman had wit in her madness, however; for she secreted her paraphernalia, and her chariot has rolled on her personal fortune, ever since. Women are much wiser, now-a-days, than they used to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Williams.
SP.P: Your Ladyship's masquerade dress is just come home, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Let me see! let me see!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: How beautiful! My dear crea∣ture, You'll look a Goddess, and you'll move a Queen!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Ah, Bromley! I have just recollected that I can't go as a Sultana. I have sent my ear-rings to be altered, and the rest of my jewels will make no figure without them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Hire, hire, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: What a baby, Mrs. Williams! but 'tis a sweet baby, we must allow. Why, for fifty, or a hundred guineas, at most, you may hire as many diamonds as would out-blaze the throne of Dehli.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: A hundred guineas! What a sum for one night's vanity! No—I'll go as a Shepherdess.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: That wou'd be a disguise, indeed, in these days of martial ardour, when our whole Sex have exchanged their old fashion'd simplicity of dress and manners, for the military air, the smart cockade, and lively regimental.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: But one may be allowed to look inno∣cent in masquerade, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Ha, my little fly one! have I found you out?—Nothing but a Corydon cou'd have inspired such an idea.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: All dresses, I fancy, are alike to Mr. Woodley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Mr. Woodley! Ridiculous! Why, surely, my dear, you don't think of exposing your∣self to be the jest of the whole Town, by going en groupe with your husband to a Masquerade!—Would not the dear, good natured Sir Harry Granger, or even the wise Colonel Mountfort, make a better Corydon for our sweet Shepherdess, think you?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: How idly you talk!—Mountfort is Louisa's Cecisbeo, and Sir Harry, I fancy, would be proud to enlist under your banner, in the same capacity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: This is wilful blindness, Lady Mary, for you can't avoid seeing that Sir Harry is your slave. I pity him with all my heart, and wsh you would do so too. Poor soul, how he doats upon you!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You'll make me angry, Mrs. Bromley.—But, prithee, why must I be treated like a picture for a drawing room, not to be hung up without its companion? I want no Corydon, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: No, to be sure—quite lonely and discreet. Come, come, my dear Lady Mary, you were not designed for a simple Shepherdess:—the Sultana is your natural character—born to command, and be adored. But you must and shall be fine; for let the men say what they will of native charms, our diamonds add considerably to the lustre of our eyes. What say you, Mrs. Williams?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Williams.
SP.P: There never was a truer word spoken, Ma'am; for though my Lady wants no off∣settings, and looks like an angel in any dress—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: A truce with your flattery, Williams!—Take away the dress—I shall consider of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Williams.
SP.P: Nobody's flattery will go down, now, but Mrs. Bromley's, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary
SP.P: I should like the Sultana, I confess; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: But what?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Can't you guess? You know I have been stripped at play, and have squandered a great deal of money, this morning. I am sorry I bought these toys.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Bless me! how you talk? you that have the fondest, and the most indulgent husband breathing!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: For that very reason, my dear Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: You really talk like a wife of the last century.—Here's a fuss, indeed, about a poor hundred guineas! Do you know, now, that I would not have this story told of you, in any polite circle, for treble the sum.—If it should take wind, you'd be sneered to death with encomiums on your Lady∣ship's very uncommon prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P:
Why, I should not care to be thought
too prudent, neither; so I beg you'll not mention it to any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: You may rely on my friendship.—And now, my Dear, what jewels would you have?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You can't imagine how much distressed I am, upon this trifling subject. I'm resolved not to ask Mr Woodley for money, to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Borrow, then. You may com∣mand thousands, to my knowledge. Sir Harry is as rich as all Duke's Place, and I am sure he would be happy to lay all his treasures at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Borrow money from Sir Harry Gran∣ger!—You cannot mean it!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Sure never mortal was so easily taken-in, as my dear Lady Mary! You could not think me serious, I hope.—Not but I know many wives—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Who are a reproach to their Sex, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: No preaching, if you love me!—I shall get the jewels for you, on my own credit; for I am resolved that you shall not only be the loveliest, but the finest woman, in all that dear, gay, motley Assembly, to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I thank you, my dear Bromley.—I think the dress will become me.—But I owe you a monstrous deal of money, I'm afraid, already.—How much is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: A trifle, a very trifle, indeed, between such friends! and I shall be apt to quarrel with you, if ever you mention it again—let the men settle it.—I shall bring the jewels with me at five; 'till then, adio mia cara.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Mr. Bromley comes, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Lord! who knows any thing of a Husband's engagements, my Dear? But there is no doubt of his attending your summons, on any occa∣sion, for my poor Bromley dies for you. You are quite a monopolizer, Lady Mary!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: What a rattle you are!
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM's Apartment
Sir WILLIAM and Mr. BELFORD at Back-gammon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I tell you, I will hear no more of him.—If he has destroyed his fortune, he shall not de∣stroy my peace.— (throws the dice) Cinque ace.—Come, come, 'tis your throw.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: It is amazing, Sir William, that you can be so anxious about this trifling game, and at the same time so indifferent about your nephew!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I am in earnest about every thing, Mr. Belford; consequently, in my resentment against my silly nephew, who is a slave to his wife, and a victim to his vanity. Will you take the box, I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Gently, gently, my good Sir William.—You have put yourself in a passion, already.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No, Sir, 'tis you that have put me in a passion.—I hate gently, and all the phlegmatic people in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: And yet you and I have been friends, these twenty years.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: True, true, my dear Belford!—and, perhaps, I am indebted to your gently, for our conti∣nuing so.—But don't put my patience to any further trial, at present.—Sit down, I entreat you.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: But one word more, and I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, I am patient, but don't harp again on the same string—No more of Mr. Wood∣ley.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: You have a noble fortune, Sir William!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, thanks to Providence! more than I have occasion for myself, and therefore I consider the overplus but as a bank for my friends.—Do you want money, Belford? Name the sum, and take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Thank you, Sir William, but 'tis not my wants I wish you to supply, but those of your nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What! at it again? I will not give him a doit—not a doit, Sir. My fortune shall not be lavished to indulge his vanity, or supply his prodigality.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I am persuaded he has so thoroughly re∣flected upon his past folly, that he would make a proper use of your future kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Let him alter his conduct, first, if he expects I should alter mine. His repentance may merit my bounty; but my liberality shall not pre∣vent his reformation.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: But if Mr. Woodley should be undone, what will become of your niece?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Let her share his fate, as she has done his folly—she has earned it.—An extravagant woman, that could not be content to live at one of the finest Seats in England, but must frisk it to Spa and Paris, forsooth, like the rest of the silly English, to squander their money, and be laughed at by Foreigners!

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I understood Miss Woodley had remain∣ed in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What, Louisa! I did not speak of her—she is the best girl on earth.—No, no—she shan't suffer for other people's faults. If he has involved her fortune too, I shall take care of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Do you intend she shall live with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No, Sir, no—I'll have no mistress in my house, but old Jones. I would not displace her for a Duchess—it would break the poor woman's heart.—But I shall take proper care of Louisa.— (aside) I wish she was well married, out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: But now give me leave, Sir William—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Neither now, nor then, Mr. Belford. The matter is all settled in my mind, and the game gone quite out of my head. I'll send for Louisa, directly, and talk this matter over with her.—Waters! (enter Waters) Step in to Mr. Woodley's, and desire my niece to come to me immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I am sorry I have been so unsuccessful in my suit, Sir William, and wish you a good-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: You are not angry with me, I hope, Belford?—I am as sorry for my nephew's indiscre∣tion as you or any one can be.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: If you are, you will certainly assist him. (aside) But I know it must be all done in your own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Dine with me, and we'll play out our party, after dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: With all my heart, but I shall be too many for you, as usual.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: If I had not the greatest regard ima∣ginable for my old friend, I should hate him abominably, for always beating me at backgammon. But let me consider, now—She has ten thousand pounds of her own. I will give her as much more, at present, and my whole estate, after my death.—No, no,—that won't be acting justly—Woodley may have children—They have not offended me, though their father has;—and if they should be half so pleasant as he was when he was a child, I should love them dearly, as I once did him. But I must strive to forget all that business, now.—Here comes Louisa.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady MARY, who keeps at a distance, without Sir WILLIAM's looking at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, child; you know, I suppose, that my hopeful nephew is totally ruined—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why don't you come nearer? I wouldn't have all the house hear me.— (she advances) My nephew, I tell you, is ruined.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I could not have imagined, Sir, when you did me the honour of sending for me, that you meant to alarm or insult me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I send for you! I in∣sult you!—That blundering Waters!—No, Madam, you are the last person in the world, except your husband, that I should think of sending for.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: The respect I have for you, Sir, as Mr. Woodley's relation, must make it extremely painful to me to know that I am so disagreeable to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Respect for me, Madam! I don't de∣sire your respect, nor deserve your respect.— (aside) If she talks in this way, she'll stagger my resolution.—I wanted to speak with my niece, Madam, and my blundering servant—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Has brought you one that is proud of that title, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: You have a title of your own, Madam.—I hate titles—and one reason why I never married, was because I would not have my wife called my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I see, Sir William, that you are not inclined—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: To converse with Ladies, Madam.—I would speak with Louisa, upon business.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I shall no longer obtrude on you, Sir; but before I go, must request you'll explain what you meant by saying that Mr. Woodley was ruined.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
She knows nothing of the matter, I find, and I cannot bear to shock her.—I think, Madam, you ought to understand that matter as well as I.—Ruined!—Why, 'tis a common phrase, at present, Madam.—Dukes, Lords, and Commons, nay, the whole Nation, are ruined, Ma∣dam—'tis
quite the Ton; and I suppose that neither Mr. Woodley nor you would chuse to be out of the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, you'll allow that Mr. Woodley's fortune, and my rank, entitles us—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: To be ruined in good company, Ma∣dam.— (aside.) She has touched the right key now. I'm no more afraid of her. Had she fallen a-crying, I might have been ruined too.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I am sorry to find, Sir, that your pre∣judices against Mr. Woodley and me are so strong, that it would be in vain for us to attempt a justifi∣cation of our conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Quite so, indeed, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I shall therefore take my leave, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: You have mine, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Shall I send Miss Woodley to you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No, Madam, no; I'll send for her when I am a little more composed. Your servant—your servant, Madam.— [Exit Lady Mary]—Waters!—What a martyrdom has this fellow exposed me to!—Waters!— (enter Waters)—Thou eternal blockhead, dolt, dunderhead—

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: Does your Honour speak to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No; to the door; to the window; to this table—Matter itself has more intelligence than thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Would your Honour please to have dinner served? It is quite ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Let it wait.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Belford is below, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, well, I'll go then. What a provoking blunder!

If Belford should succeed with my uncle, all may yet be well. Something must be done, and quickly too. I can no longer endure the agony of endea∣vouring to impose upon the world, and myself, by personating a borrowed character. But here she comes, who innocently adds to all my sufferings, and tips the darts of poverty with anguish!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: O! my dear Woodley! such a trial ordeal as I have undergone! I declare I would ra∣ther be buried alive, in Dorsetshire, than endure such another tête-à-tête. He has done every thing, but beat me.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I don't comprehend you—Whom do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Nay, that's downright perverseness; for I am certain there is not such another creature upon earth, as your precious Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I hope you have not quarrelled with him, Lady Mary?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: No, truly; he has spared me that trouble, by quarrelling with me, most outrageously.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Then all my hopes in Belford are at an end. I am very sorry you happened to come in his way.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I'm sure so am I, Mr. Woodley. The interview was not of my seeking; and though I was as mild as a lamb, he was as rude as a bear. The deuce take his blundering servant for bringing me into such a scrape!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I should hope that your regard for me would have prevented—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P:
And so it did, I assure you; for I did not laugh, tho' he said something so ridiculous,
about your being ruined, the Nation being ruined, and all the world being ruined, that I had much ado to keep my countenance. However, I behaved very decently all the while, and even condescended to en∣treat that he would give you leave to justify your conduct to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: And did my dear Mary obtain his per∣mission?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Your earnestness startles me, Mr. Woodley. Of what consequence can the old-fashion∣ed opinion of an obstinate Don Choleric, who hates us both, be of to us? I wish he would endow an Hospital with his fortune, that our solicitude to please might end with our expectations.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Mine should not, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: That must be as you please, Mr. Woodley; but I declare, that from this hour—

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Make no rash vows, Madam. You know not how much you have been, or may be, in∣debted to Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I indebted to him! No, Mr. Woodley, that I positively deny.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: And so do I, with both my hands, and all my heart; for be the question in Law, Physic, or Divinity, I'll pawn my life on't, that Lady Mary is right.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I am much obliged to you for your good opinion, Mr. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: And I wager on Mr. Woodley's side, were it only to keep up the argument. The question, then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Ay, ay, the question?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: There are secrets in all families, you know, my dear Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: And it is always prudent to keep them so, Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Very good, very good, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Curiosity, thank heaven, is not one of my failings. 'Tis ever a mark both of igno∣rance and ill-breeding. I am astonished how any one can be infected with such an impertinent weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Yes, yes, my Dame is quite above all silly curiosity— (aside.) The veriest eaves-dropper that ever existed. She'll not rest 'till she has got the whole story, and I shall have it the moment we get home.
SP.STAGE: Mrs. Bromley shews a Box of Jewels to Lady Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: They are quite charming, indeed! I shall outblaze the Queen of Diamonds.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: What jewels are these? I hope you have not bought them, Lady Mary!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You hope I have not bought them—What an odd speech, Mr. Woodley! No; I have only borrowed them, and will lend you part, if you'll go en Turc. I can spare enough to ornament his turban, can't I, Bromley?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Surely you don't persist in making a family party, Lady Mary?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You shall have these.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Prithee, don't teize me, Lady Mary—I shall not go to the Masquerade.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Don't teize me! Something extraordinary must have disturbed him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: You'll have a charming squeeze at your rout, Lady Mary! Not a vacant chair to be found in the whole house, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You flatter me. No; I believe there will hardly be any body. Do you know that I have had a hundred and ninety-one excuses within these two days?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P:
Ay, but you'll have nine hundred
and ninety people, for all that. I hope Lady Sitfast won't come! That woman never orders her carriage till near one, tho' she plagues the servant to call it up, every five minutes after eleven.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Then there's that poor, drooping Mrs. Henpeck, who always loses, and sits moaning over her losses, and playing the after-game, 'till the ser∣vants are obliged to put her out along with the candles.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: No more excuses, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Dinner is served, please your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Is Sir Harry Granger come?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: O, no; he has no longer the entrée here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: I'm heartily sorry for it. No man tem∣pers a sallad like Sir Harry. He is a perfect com∣pendium of the whole art of cookery, and has more good receipts in his pocket-book, than ever were published by the celebrated Hannah Glass.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Most excellent qualifications for a man of fashion!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: True, very true, indeed! Eating is the rage, the high ton, at present, and indeed is one of the most refined of our modern studies.—Will your Ladyship permit me the transcendant honour of your fair hand?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I attend Mrs. Bromley.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir WILLIAM and Mr. BELFORD at a Table, with a Bottle and Glasses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I AM no drinking man myself, Belford; but yet I do not approve of this water system of yours. It keeps the spirits too low—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: To say or do any thing mad or foolish, I grant it may. But if water does not raise, it never depresses the spirits. Can you say as much for your generous wine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, well, I won't dispute with you, because I hate argument; and as you are an honest fellow, I can venture to take my glass chearfully in your company, tho' you don't partake of my liquor. But I'd give something, ay, more than I'll mention, that you'd share only one pint of claret with me, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I have made no vows, Sir William; and to humour a friend can easily dispense with rules of my own making: So here's your fair niece, Louisa Woodley, in a bumper.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Thank you, thank you, my good friend! She is a most excellent girl, and I like to have her toasted by such a man as you. I wish she was well settled, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: There can be no doubt of her marrying to advantage. She is a fine young woman, with a fine fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
And so may be sacrificed to some fine young man, that may spend her fortune in finery, as her hopeful brother has done, and leave her a beg∣gar.
No, no,—I'll prevent that—I have thought of a match for her—Fill your glass, Belford!—a prudent, sober, sensible man.— (aside) I wish he'd take the hint.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Rare qualities, indeed, for a young man of fashion to possess, in these days, Sir Wil∣liam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Who told you that he was a young man of fashion? Why, Sir, there have been no men born, at least, for these last thirty years—all monkies and macaronies. No Hearts of Oak, now, Belford,—all dwindled, dwindled into aspens!

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Your sarcasm is rather too general, my good friend. Courage is the birth-right of an Englishman, and while one acre of our soil remains, both the Oak and the Laurel will thrive on it.—We must not prejudge the rising generation; and I have not the least doubt but your niece will make a very proper choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: A choice! I hope she has been better educated, than to have a choice, Sir. I was not consulted in her brother's match, and you see the consequence.—I shall dispose of Louisa in my own way.—I have a husband now in my eye for her, Belford.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Whoever obtains Miss Woodley, will, I dare say, be a very happy man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Stick to that, my dear Belford.—Yes, yes, whoever marries Louisa will be a very happy man, and I am extremely glad you think so.— (aside) I wish he'd come to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: You know, Sir William, that I have long been acquainted with Miss Woodley's merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: You charm me, my dear Belford. I am glad you know her worth, and you will therefore cherish it.—She is mild and timid—but you'll be kind and gentle to her, even for my sake, my good old friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Kind and gentle to her! and your good old friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, are not you my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Most certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Then why all this reiteration? If you marry Louisa—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I marry her, Sir William!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—Did you not, this moment, allow that who ever married her, would be a very happy man? And I suppose, you can have no possible objection to being a very happy man, Mr. Belford?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, the strongest in the world, if my happiness is to be purchased at the expence of another's misery.—But I am wrong for being serious, when I am certain you do but jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: In the first place, Sir, I never said any thing in jest, since I was born.—And, secondly, Sir, I never was more in earnest, in the whole course of my life. I therefore request from you a serious answer.—Jest, indeed! No, truly, Counsellor, I am no joker.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Why, then, Sir, I should think myself highly honoured—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Psha, psha, psha—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Patience, my good friend—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No, Sir—I will have no patience with your nonsensical compliments—none of your ho∣nours, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: In a word, then, Sir William, the disparity of years between forty-eight and eigh∣teen—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Is just nothing at all.—What need you tell her you are forty-eight?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: There will be no occasion, I grant you—Self-evident propositions need no proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Hark'ye, Belford, you fatigue me to death with your logic and sophistry.—The point
may be reduced to two words,—Will you marry my niece, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: It is a match so infinitely beyond my pretensions, Sir William—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I hope I may be allowed the best judge in that matter, Mr. Belford.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: By no means, Sir William, your partial kindness towards me—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Is almost worn out, by your tiresome, false modesty;—and, if I thought I should have as much plague with Louisa, as I have had with you, I'd renounce my project, and leave her to die an old maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: The proposal is so highly favourable to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: That you consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Were I certain that Miss Woodley's inclinations—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I told you, before, that I could dis∣pose of them as I pleased; so that if you have no other objection, I shall carry my point, and settle one of my family to my entire satisfaction, at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: It is impossible that I can have any objection, if she has none.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your hand then, my dear Belford—'Tis a match.—Order your clerks to set about the writings directly.—Your estate lies in Staffordshire, I think.—You know I add ten thousand to her fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: But surely, my dear Sir William, Miss Woodley ought to be made acquainted—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, has she not been acquainted with you ever since she was born? If I mistake not, you were present at her christening.—The wedding shall be next week—The sooner my dear girl is happily settled, the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Your kindness overwhelms me—but still, Miss Woodley—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Shall be made acquainted with her happiness, this evening. I leave all the articles of settlement to your own honour.—I know you'll make a proper provision for my niece, because it is pos∣sible you may die before her—but no pin-money, I charge you—'Tis but a prelude to alimony, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I shall endeavour to acquit myself as such a generous confidence deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Hurry, hurry your clerks, and bring this happy event to a speedy conclusion, my dear nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I have the strongest motives to enforce their diligence, as well as the highest sense of my obligations to your friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No speeches—hasten the business, and adieu.— [Exit Belford.]—I'll speak to Jones, direct∣ly, to prepare for the wedding-dinner. She can't bear to be hurried; and I'd have every thing mag∣nificent on that day, which I shall deem the happiest of my whole life; because it will be the first time I could ever get any of my family to know their own interest, and act as I would have them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I am very glad to see you, my dear child.—And now what have you to say to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I was informed, Sir, by my sister, that you desired to speak with me, and I am therefore come to receive your commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, my dear, it will neither be ques∣tions nor commands, but cross-purposes, if you keep at such a distance as will make it impossible we should hear one another. Come nearer, I say—What are you afraid of?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
So, so—that will do.—And now, my dear child, you can't imagine what a heavenly tem∣per
I am in, and what favourable dispositions I have towards you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I am very happy, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: So you'll say, my dear, when you know all. But you must deserve my kindness, by your frankness;—therefore, first tell me, whether you have any particular objection to matrimony?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: It is a subject, Sir, that I have never much thought upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: That's singular, now; for I am told that the girls of these days think of nothing else. But, luckily, there is no occasion for your considering about the matter, as you have such a friend as I am to consider for you, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: And so I shall make your mind easy at once, by letting you know that I have provided a husband for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (aside.) Now, Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: And such a one as is not to be met with every day, I assure you—a man after my own heart—has not a fault, Louisa, but that he is a water-drinker. But I won't anticipate, by telling you his name. He shall surprise you with it him∣self.—Why, hey!—what's the matter now? You don't seem at all overjoyed!—You are not hankering after a title, I hope; for, believe me, niece, if there be either happiness or virtue left in the present world, they are only to be met with in the middle ranks of life. What makes you tremble so?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You are not unacquainted with my ti∣midity, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I understand the timidity of your whole sex— (aside.) Doves before mar∣riage, and Kites after.—You'll soon get the bet∣ter of your timidity, I'll answer for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: As I am certain, Sir, that 'tis your wish to make me happy—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: You are right, my dear; but it must be my own way. Your brother's want of respect to my opinion, you see, has been his ruin, child. Don't attempt to copy him, Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: If you would but condescend to hear me, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, child, I know every thing already, that you would wish to say. Your obligations to me, and your modesty, and your timidity, and your settlement, and all that—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Dear Sir, I have not a thought about a settlement—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, well, every thing shall be taken care of, except a provision for a separate mainte∣nance. I bar that; for if you can't live happily with such a husband as I have chosen for you, I should think you deserved to starve, tho' you were my niece a thousand times.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: But, my dear uncle—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: But, my dear niece, don't insist upon it; for a woman who thinks of separation at the moment of her union, does not intend to abide by her husband, as she ought to do, 'till death do them part.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I neither think of union nor separation, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Modest and virtuous that—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Hear me but one word, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Enough's said, enough's said, my dear. Here, take this bill, to provide for your dress. I'd have every thing handsome. The ladies are great belles in Staffordshire; and I'd have my niece make as good an appearnace as any private gentlewoman among them. Why don't you take the bill? 'Tis for five hundred pounds, and I hope you think that sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I have no sort of occasion for it, Sir; and if you would but indulge me with a moment's conversation—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Psha, psha, psha,—I hate all this af∣fected delicacy. Take money from the old man whenever you can get it. Hasten your milliners and mantua-makers, and get all your matters ready by this day se'nnight, for I won't have the wedding de∣ferred an hour longer. Delays are ever dangerous.
SP.STAGE: (Exit, throwing the bill on the table.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: What, in the name of wonder, can this dear, kind, cruel uncle of mine intend for me? I almost doubt whether I wake or not. Married in a week, to a man perhaps I never saw! No, that's impossible—he is too good to think of such an union. Possibly Mountfort may have applied for his consent, before he asked mine!—Too fond a hope, I fear.—I wish I could see Counsellor Belford; my uncle keeps no secret from him, and he is a friend to all our fa∣mily. I'll write to him to come to me instantly.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mr. Belford, without seeing Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I cannot proceed on this business, in earnest, till Sir William has had some conference with his niece. It is possible she may dislike the match, or perhaps be otherwise engaged—and then I should become the standing jest of all my brother Benchers. I must speak to Sir William again.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My good Mr. Belford, I never was so glad to see you in my whole life. I have been this moment writing to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: You make me the happiest of mortals, Madam.— (aside This Brief opens well! I need not be much afraid of being laughed at now.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: There is something so particular— (aside I know not how to mention it—Mr. Belford, my good uncle has—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I find completed his kindness, and ac∣quainted you, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No, Sir, but as you share his confidence, I must entreat that you'll inform me— (besitates)

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: (aside) Her modesty distresses me vastly; but I like her the better for it! I wish I had a speech ready.—Did not Sir William, Madam, say any thing of matrimony to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You can't imagine, Sir, how he has sur∣prised and terrified me, by talking of my being to be married in a week.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: You might be surprised, to be sure, Ma∣dam; but I don't see any occasion for your being terrified, any more than for such a violent hurry. The writings can't be properly engrossed in that time. The Law seldom keeps pace with a Lover's wishes;—and however impatient I may be to expedite this business, you shall not be hurried, fair Lady, but be at liberty to name your own day.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: It shall be Doomsday, then—However, I thank you, Sir, for allowing me even a reprieve.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: (aside) Hey-dey! Where sits the wind now?—You have no absolute aversion to marriage, I hope, Miss Woodley?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I despise affectation, Sir, and am above disguise, with an old friend like you:—I have no aversion to marriage, when I can bestow my hand with my heart;—but I would rather die, than be sa∣crificed to a frightful fordid wretch, who has tre∣panned my uncle out of his consent, because he de∣spaired of mine, and takes me merely as an appen∣dage to my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: (aside) How lucky was my coming back!—But why should you suppose, Madam, that your uncle would sacrifice you to a frightful sordid wretch? Your intended husband is a very different kind of man, I'll assure you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Let him be what he will, Sir, I shall de∣test him.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I never thought, Miss Woodley, that my conduct or character had in any instance merit∣ed your detestation, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Detest you, Mr. Belford! No, that's impossible!—But how are you concerned in the mat∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Not much, at present, Madam;—for I scorn to take advantage of your uncle's engagements, unless ratified by your consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Oh, Mr. Belford!

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Nay, never whimper about it. I own, I suspected, from the first, that it was rather too good news to be true:—but don't make yourself unhappy, Miss Woodley; for I would rather live and die a batchelor, than marry the finest woman in England, as is now the case (bowing), who was not equally ready to have and to hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Generous, worthy man!

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Not more generous than prudent, Ma∣dam, on this occasion. But, as I hope I have now deserved your confidence, Miss Woodley, tell me then, if you have any particular attachment, and I shall endeavour to serve you with Sir William;—though I know I shall, for a time, stand in the light of a culprit before him, by declining the honour he intended me.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You overpower me with obligations, Mr. Belford.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: No speeches, my dear Madam. If I was not sufficiently gratified by the honour of the act, no acknowledgements could make me amends for the disappointment; so frankly name the hap∣py man who is to raise my envy, and compleat your happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Though I think that a well-placed and mutual affection need not raise a blush upon the chastest cheek, yet mine will glow when I name Co∣lonel Mountfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Colonel Mountfort! I'm sorry for it▪

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Why so, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Because he's a very pretty fellow, Ma∣dam, and for that reason may fall within your un∣cle's chapter of coxcombs, and prevent his consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Then I shall never give mine to marry any man else.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: That's somewhat in the Knight's own stile, Miss Woodley. But I heartily wish you suc∣cess, and shall shew myself a warmer Friend than a Lover, by using my best pleadings in my rival's suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Accept my warmest thanks, my good old friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Ay, ay,—I knew she would always think of me as her old friend.
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Mr. WOODLEY's. A Dining-Room.
Mr. WOODLEY and Mr. BROMLEY at a Table, with a Dice-Box.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I'll play no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, my dear friend, luck has run confoundedly against you; but I never saw you give out for such a trifling loss, before.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Seven hundred pounds is no trifle, Mr. Bromley!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: A trifle, indeed, to a person of your immense fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: You have made a false estimate of my circumstances. I am rather a distressed man, at present, Mr. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: (aside) Are you so? Then 'tis time for me to take care of myself.—You surprise me vastly! Distressed did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I hate to repeat it; but 'tis so true, that I had some thoughts of applying to your friend∣ship, to extricate me out of my present difficulties, Mr. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Command me, command me, my dear Woodley! Every thing that poor Bob Brom∣ley has in the world— (aside) except his money,—is at your service.—But let us clear as we go—settle our little matters first—just set your name to this paper—or will you take another throw, my friend, and let it be double or quit?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: For shame, Woodley!—at hazard in your own house! I thought you had enough of that at Clubs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Play among friends is wrong, very wrong, I confess, Colonel; but one can't be always grave and wise.—Come, my dear Woodley, let us make an end of our business—the pen, or the box, my dear boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Desperate situations require desperate remedies.—Give me the box— (they throw) Damn the dice!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: 'Tis double, now, you know, my unlucky friend; which makes upon the whole ex∣actly the sum of seven thousand three hundred and fifty-four pounds, including the dear Lady Mary's trifling debt to Mrs. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: True, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Well, I have brought a bond with me, and when I have filled up the blanks, if you please we'll perfect it in the next room.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: With all my heart.— (aside.) Sure ne∣ver man was so completely unfortunate! Never, by Heaven, will I touch a die again!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P:
Then I give you joy of your losses; for I
know you are too much a man of honour to break your vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Gamesters, like lovers, you know, Colonel—And after all, now, this is but matter of form between friends and men of honour, like you and me.—Don't you think so, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I consider all compulsive obligations be∣tween men as a disgrace to human nature. But while there are such things as knaves in the world, Mr. Bromley, we must submit to the mean securities of bars and bonds. But between men of honour, as you say—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Certainly, my dear Sir, men of ho∣nour are—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Too often the dupes of knaves, Mr. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: I don't like him.—We'll talk over the affair you hinted at in the next room. Command me, on all occasions—ever—ever at your service. But I must attend the ladies. The ladies and the coffee are powerful attractions to me. You'll follow me, I presume, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Yes, with pleasure, through my whole re∣giment, with a drum at your heels. I am persuaded, Woodley, that fellow is a knave, and I wish you would exclude both him and his flaunting wife from your's and Lady Mary's society. I can't con∣ceive why you are so partial to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: The great civilities we received from them, at Spa, first attached my wife to Mrs. Brom∣ley, who was there in the first sets, and even in Lon∣don, where people are more nice. She keeps very good company, I assure you, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P:
You'll pardon me, Woodley!—She is seldom seen in public but with some damaged Dowager of Quality, who would be excluded from society if her title did not serve as a herald to make way for her Ladyship.—But enough of them! I am come to speak to you on a much more interesting subject,
and to prove—what, however, I cannot doubt—your friendship for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Be assured, my dear Mountfort—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I am so—you need not make professions;—therefore, with the frankness of a soldier, I venture to ask the highest proof of your regard, by consent∣ing to make the fair Louisa mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: My sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You seem to hesitate, Mr. Woodley! My fortune is—

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: As unexceptionable as your character, Colonel; and as I truly love Louisa, and should rejoice in her happiness—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You consent to mine. Is it so, my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I know not how to answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You alarm me extremely, Mr. Woodley! For heaven's sake, speak out!—What can be your objections?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: None in the world, to you; but cir∣cumstanced as I am at present, it would involve me in the greatest difficulties, to be called upon so sud∣denly for ten thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That shall not be the case, Woodley. I should think even Louisa too dearly purchased, at the expence of distressing you. When I asked for your sister's hand, I did not demand her purse; nor shall I accept the one, 'till I have signed a release for the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
