SP.P: Mountfort, that must not, shall not be! I never will accept of such a sacrifice.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Hark-ye, Woodley! A soldier's character should be uniform; and if there could be one who was not liberal, I should suspect his courage to be of the mere animal kind. My fortune is sufficiently ample; and I would as soon mount my charger, cry stand and deliver, as take money I don't want, from a friend who does.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Your generosity, Colonel—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Is of too selfish a nature to merit praise; for I feel here (laying his hand to his heart) that the true luxury of fortune lies more in giving, than in spending.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I will not lessen it, by offering thanks. But have you opened your trenches before the Knight of the Castle yet? (pointing to the middle door) He used to speak well of you, and his opinion is of some consequence in this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: My sentiments are even with the good old Knight's, I assure you. I esteem his good qualities, and do not dislike even his foibles, as they are truly natural and unsophisticate. But there, perhaps, you may see me play the usurer, like any Jew. He may double or treble Louisa's fortune, without the least impediment from any scruple or modesty of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: When do you purpose to make the essay?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: As soon as possible; for 'till I have paid the proper respect due to him, I do not think myself entitled to throw myself at Louisa's feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: May success attend you, my generous friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Fie, Woodley—no more of that!—But adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: AND so that was all?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Every word, I assure you. But we shall soon make it up, for ours are but lovers' quarrels.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Lovers! talk of love after four years marriage! Believe me, Lady Mary, 'tis all a farce.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: No, my dear Mrs. Bromley, I cannot give you credit against the feelings of my own heart. I love Mr. Woodley, and I am firmly per∣suaded that he has a sincere affection for me, not∣withstanding the little peevishness of his behaviour to-day, which I own makes me apprehend that something must have ruffled him extremely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: How did you like his peremptory resolve, of passing the whole summer in Dorset∣shire?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Not at all, I confess; 'tis frightful to think of it—though there is a tolerable neighbour∣hood—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Of empty houses.—No creature stays at their family seats, now-a-days, unless it be some antiquated Dowager, who, like an old Gothic corner cupboard, remains fixed to the freehold.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I vow I won't go into the country—'tis quite mauvais ton—except you'll come with us; and then we'll fly about to all the bathing-places, and give a masquerade at one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I should like to pass a few weeks so, well enough;—and, indeed, my dear, you'll be quite forgotten, if you don't do something in that way. But are you sure that Mr. Woodley would like it? for I must say, though I ask your pardon, Lady Mary, he is dull—absolutely dull, indeed, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Why, I own, of late he has been rather gloomy;—but he is vastly good-natured, and never before refused any request of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: That may be:—but had Mr. Bromley talked to me in the same manner—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You would have loved him just as well as you do now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: You are admirable at guessing, my dear;—for as that same romantic notion of love never was the band of our connexion—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You startle me, Mrs. Bromley. Mar∣riage without love must surely be a state of the greatest unhappiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: No, I don't feel in the least unhappy.—Convenience is the best matrimonial cement, and keeps many couples together for years, whose love did not out-last the honey-moon.—But these are mysteries, into which you seem not yet initiated.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I hope I shall never know them by experience.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My dear sister— (sees Mrs. Bromley) I thought you were alone; I had something in parti∣cular to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You alarm me vastly, Louisa!—What is the matter, my dear? You know I keep no secrets from Mrs. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Another time, Lady Mary. Family affairs—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Pray, my dear, make no stranger of me!— (aside) I hope Mountfort has jilted he▪ I die to know.—Has the gallant Colonel deserted, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Colonel Mountfort, Madam, is no way concerned in the present question.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Then I would not give sixpence for the whole story.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You look distressed, Louisa!—What can have happened? I'm all impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Though I had rather be excused, Lady Mary, yet as you press so earnestly to know, my Uncle—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Psha!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Has insisted on my marrying—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Not himself, hope?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Giddy creature! I Whom, my dear Louisa?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Counsellor Belford.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: And is that all? I think it a monstrous good match.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Monstrous, indeed!—Why, he's fifty, at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Fifty! fiddle-stick! What does that signify? He is rich enough for threescore; and money, money, my dear, qualifies all dis∣proportions.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: This is by much too serious a subject for jesting, Mrs. Bromley.—But Sir William is not your sole Guardian, Louisa; and your brother, I am certain, will never consent to sacrifice you to his uncle's caprice.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I would not, on any account, my dear sister, have my brother oppose Sir William in any thing, as he is already but too much offended with him. Besides, I am in hopes that there will not be any occasion for his interposing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: She's coming round, I find.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Bromley, Madam, has sent the car∣riage, and desires to speak with you, at home, im∣mediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I'm glad of the release.—What now can he possibly want with me? But I am all obedience, though it breaks my heart to leave you. But I shall return quickly, before any one sits down to Loo.—And so, my dear, (to Louisa) I leave you to settle your important matters, which should be soon determined, were you my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Thank Heaven, I am not!—She is levity itself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Her lightness, Louisa, extends no farther than her manners:—her morals are irre∣proachable; and when the mind is untainted, its gaiety, like a coloured trimming to a grave suit, serves only to enliven it.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You are too partial, sister; for I much fear that you will one day discover Mrs. Bromley's manners and morals to be both of a piece.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: No more upon the subject, at pre∣sent!—and in truth I wonder how you can have spirits to talk of any thing else but your own melan∣choly situation.—Married to Belford! to your Grandfather!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I should be sad, indeed, if such a marriage was to take place;—but my Intended has generously consented to break off the match, at my request, and to screen me from Sir William's displeasure, at the same time.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Then the old Barrister is charming, and I think I could be a little in love with him myself. But I cannot submit to this new insult from Sir William! What could he mean by dis∣posing of you without deigning to consult Mr. Woodley? I shall insist upon an explanation of his conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I again intreat you, Lady Mary, not to involve my brother farther with Sir William—you do not know the consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I am quite weary of all this temporiz∣ing, Louisa; and as you are safe on shore, you must allow me to guide the helm for myself, at present.—You'll permit me, at least, to acquaint Mr. Woodley with his uncle's contemptuous neglect of him in this matter, which I shall go and do directly.
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM's Apartments.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, for once, Waters, I will ac∣knowledge myself the happiest man in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Waters.
SP.P: I am proud to hear that your Honour is so well pleased.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I am pleased, and I won't be pleased alone—they shall be pleased too!—They shall have a noble service of plate!—Louisa deserves every thing—she behaved like an angel! I thought I should have had more trouble with her; but though it be strange, it is certainly true, that all girls like to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Colonel Mountfort, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I shall be glad to see him.—Wa't on him up, Waters. (Exeunt Waters and Servant) The Colonel is a very good young man, as young men go, at present—but nothing to compare to what his father was.
I am very glad to see you, my young friend. Set chairs, Waters.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I am much obliged to you, Sir William, and happy to perceive by your looks that all in∣quiries after your health must be superfluous.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I thank you, Sir!—I fancy, indeed, I do look tolerably well, for serenity of mind goes a great way towards clearing up the countenance; and I do not know when my spirits have ever been so harmo∣nized, as at this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: How fortunate!—May I flatter myself, Sir William, that the present happy temper of your mind will assist my suit, and render you propitious!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Propitious! Nonsense.—You are an idle young rogue!—With such a noble fortune as yours—But I won't scold, now.—You have been on the Turf, I suppose, or fleeced at the Gaming-table?—But I hope the Terra Firma is safe. I should be grieved to see my old friend's estate in the hands of knaves or sharpers.—What sum do you want? I know you to be a man of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You quite amaze me, Sir, by suspicions which, I will be bold to say, are unworthy both of Sir William Woodley and me. I am no gam∣bler, Sir, nor have I dissipated the noble inheri∣tance derived from my ancestors.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I am heartily glad of it, Sir!—I ask your pardon, young man.— (aside) What the deuce, then, can he want from me?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: If I were so unfortunately weak, as you for a moment seemed to imagine, the respect I bear you, would have prevented my applying to you upon such an occasion, as your good opinion, Sir, is of the greatest consequence to my happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: There you are wrong, Colonel;—you had much better apply to me, than to any one else.—I am no cent. per cent. man—I never received a shilling interest from any friend in my life; and I have my doubts whether I should even take it from the Funds, now that the Nation is so poor.—But come, Colonel, if you don't want money, in what other way can I possibly serve you? I have no in∣terest at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You have an interest, Sir, in what is far dearer to me than either wealth or preferment:—your lovely niece, Louisa, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Thank Heaven, she is better disposed of!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You pause!—Do not keep me on the rack, Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I was only recollecting myself.—Am much obliged to you, Sir, for the honour—I think that's the phrase—you intend my niece; but she's married, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Married, Sir William!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, Sir,—married, and settled in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: This raillery is rather cruel, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I never joke, Sir.—I have passed my word that she shall be married this day se'nnight; and if all the Emperors, Kings, Princes, and Po∣tentates in Europe, nay the Great Mogul himself, were to demand her in marriage, William Woodley would not forfeit his promise: so that married she is, to all intents and purposes, my gay Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: And has Miss Woodley consented, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Ay, to be sure; I force no-body.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Confusion!—Impossible, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why should you think so? She is a modest, dutiful girl. It would be hard, indeed, if I was to have no comfort in my family. But don't be disheartened, Colonel! Many a gallant soldier has met with a repulse, before now.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: If you could conceive the tenderness of my affection for Miss Woodley, Sir, you would not treat my sufferings so slightly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: It may be a disappointment, to be sure, Sir, for she is a fine young woman, I confess; but my friend has her, Sir, and you must think of her no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: It is not in my power to obey your injunc∣tion.— (aside) I wish it were, false and ungrateful girl!—But pray, Sir, who is the envied man so doubly blessed in your friendship and Miss Wood∣ley's love?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: That's a secret, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: That, I think, I have a right to know, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What! you want to exercise your va∣lour a little—sa, sa, sa,—by challenging your ri∣val? But keep your prowess for the common foe: we cannot spare a soldier, at present, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: This treatment is unlike yourself, Sir Wil∣liam. But Miss Woodley, I suppose, will inform me;—I presume she is not bound to keep the secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: There you are wrong again, my young hero; for she really is bound by the strongest of all possible ties—the not knowing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You cannot now be serious, Sir; and I will try if I have yet power enough over Louisa's heart to make her so—for I will know my rival. Adieu, Sir William!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your servant, Colonel Huff-Cap. What a hot-brained boy! I am doubly glad Louisa has escaped him:—I would have no passionate man in the family, but myself. How lucky 'tis that Louisa does not know her husband's name!—Wo∣men should ever be kept in ignorance, to prevent mischief. I have conducted this business most ad∣mirably!—I have some doubts, however, whether my nephew should not be made acquainted with it; but he does not deserve my confidence, and he shan't vex me now.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mr. BELFORD. Sir WILLIAM runs and em∣braces him.
SP.P: Are all things going on briskly and cleverly, as they should do, my dear nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: The swiftest bowl does not always hit the jack, Sir William; and "fair and softly" is an established maxim in the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, well, we must submit; but I hope you'll use as much dispatch as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Dispatch is a term, Sir, not to be found in any Law Dictionary that I know of; and I fancy it will be a long time before the matters you talk of will be dispatched.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, surely you have a mind to try my temper, with your fair and softly! But if you knew as much as I do, you would, perhaps, think it worth while to mend your pace a little; for many things fall out between the cup and lip, Mr. Belford.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: So you'll find presently.—The most material point in this important affair does not appear to be yet adjusted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Now—what can he mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: There can be no marriage without the consent of parties; and I don't find that Miss Woodley—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: If I was not in the most heavenly tem∣per, you would put me in a rage. Have I not told you, Sir, that she had no consent, no choice, but what I please to give? And in twenty years ac∣quaintance, have you ever known me say an untruth, Sir? My niece is all compliance and gentleness; and you'll be a very happy man, my dear nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I should be unworthy of happiness, if I could enjoy it on such terms, Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter, Belford?—Your head seems to be turned with your good for∣tune, and you want to turn mine. No man that is unworthy can be happy—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: In short, Sir William—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Ay, ay, that's the thing—now you talk sense! I like in short—stick to that, my friend. If
you want more clerks, don't value expence, I'll clear all costs—You know I hate the Law's delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: No law, but that of honour, has any thing to do in this case, Sir William; and however irksome the task, I must beg you will per∣mit me to undeceive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Then you acknowledge you have de∣ceived me? I am thunder-struck!

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: No, my good friend—'tis you that have deceived yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your proposition is false, Sir. I never deceived myself, nor any one else, since I was born, Sir. I scorn and abhor deceit, Mr. Belford. But come, Sir, let me know what all this round-about tends to? Despise the chicanery of your profession, and speak as if you was a witness on the table—not a Lawyer at the bar, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I fear I shall rather appear a criminal at the bar to you, at present, Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What, then, you are married, I suppose?—have a wife already? Nay, don't smile, Sir, there is no joke in this matter; and you ought to have been hanged, if you had married my niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I think so too, though not upon the ac∣count you mention, as I give you my honour I have no wife; and if I continue in my present mood, may venture to say that I never shall have one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Mighty well, mighty ill, Mr. Belford! You have rewarded my sincere friendly attachment—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: With true gratitude, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Don't offer to say so. What! to spurn my niece with twenty thousand pounds! Let me tell you, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: That she is much too good for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why really I begin to think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I rejoice, therefore, my dear friend—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
No, Sir, don't rejoice. I am not your friend, nor ever will be your friend. You have
broke my heart—frustrated all my schemes—disap∣pointed my niece.—Poor girl, I feel for her!—Young minds are easily broken by grief.—You will have much to answer for on her account, I assure you, Mr. Belford.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I should have much more to answer for to Miss Woodley, Sir William, if I did not decline the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Decline! Zounds, Sir, I won't bear so contemptuous an expression!— (aside.) I wish I had not been quite so peremptory with the Colonel.—If I could bring myself to unsay what I have once ut∣tered, I would give Louisa to Colonel Mountsort, to vex you.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I agree with you, Sir William, that it would be a more suitable match.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Don't agree with me, Mr. Belford, I won't suffer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Allow me at least to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No, Sir, I won't allow you to say any thing, but yes, or no, to this simple question: Do you accept, or reject, my niece?

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: The phrase is rather too strong, Sir; but I have already told you, that upon mature consi∣deration, I decline the honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Confound your honour, and your con∣sideration too!—And now, Sir, I decline any further conversation, connection, or correspondence, with you; and so, Sir, I am—no—I am not, your humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: His rage will soon subside, and we shal be as good friends as ever. I am glad his resent∣ment is entirely pointed at me, as 'tis probable, that to make his niece amends for the loss of a husbnd she did not like, he may give her one she does:—and so ends, exactly as it should, the matrmonial schemes of an Old Batchelor!
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Mr. BROMLEY's. A Dining-Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I wish you would defer it till to∣morrow! It will otherwise break up the assembly, and make a monstrous bustle in the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley
SP.P: A fig for the assembly, and the bustle, too! No, no, my sweet simpleton, business of some kinds brook no delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: You have no right to complain of my simplicity, Mr. Bromley. It is thro' me that you get this money from the Woodleys.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Money, child! I have never touch∣ed above a thousand pounds of their cash yet. This piece of paper is all I have got for spending my time with a dull fool, and endeavouring to persuade him that he was a Solomon, and his silly wife the Queen of Sheba. But I must be paid for my attendance and trouble, and in a few minutes I shall convert this manuscript into the sum of seven thousand three hundred and fifty-three pounds, with costs—costs must be added.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I can have no objection to your being paid for your time and trouble, my dear. All I desire is, that you may not lay on the execution 'till to-morrow. Let us devote this evening to pleasure, my dear Brommy. I am to play gold Loo to-night, and I have a certain presentiment that I shall win considerably.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: As to your winning, I believe you are pretty secure in that point. You don't leave much to chance, I imagine, my dove. But tho' you might win, I shall lose considerably, if this bond be not put in force this very night. I have been with Woodley's attorney, Mr. Fleece'em, a very ho∣nest man, and for a small token of friendship, he has informed me, that there will be six executions in the house to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Six executions! Nay, then, they are done up, indeed, and it does not signify much keeping any further terms with them. Yet I still wish you would postpone this ugly business, 'till we are gone to the masquerade. Poor Lady Mary! it will be a sad disappointment to her, not to shew her finery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Now you talk of finery, here, look at these!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Let me see! They are Lady Mary's ear-rings!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: No; they were, my sweet innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: But how came you by them? She told me they were gone to be new-set.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: Ask no questions, but take them, and think yourself happy in such a provident husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Thank you, my dear Brom∣my! They are beautiful, indeed!—I have long wished for them, I confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: I must go and expedite this busi∣ness directly. Don't be frightened, dove, when the Bailiffs come in. They'll add to Lady Mary's squeeze, you know.—But take a little hartshorn in your pocket:—it will be proper for you to faint, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Never fear my acting properly.—But the carriage is at the door, and I have twenty places to call at. Shall I set you down at your lawyer's, to save my dear the fatigue of walking?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Bromley.
SP.P: How happy am I in such a discreet, tender wife!— (aside) A dissembling jade!—Come, dove.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I follow, my dear Brommy.— (aside.) Hateful wretch!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, An Anti-chamber, opening into a Drawing-room.
FORWARD, with a Pencil and Pocket-book. A Foot man in the Drawing-room, placing Card-Tables for a Rout.

SP.SPEAKER: FORWARD.
SP.P: FOUR gold Loo tables, with Monsters—Four pund four!—Two at half-crowns! Thrust them to the lower end of the room, James; they are seldom worth more than twelve shillings a piece.

SP.SPEAKER: James.
SP.P: Where shall I fix the Whist tables, Mr. Forward?

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Damn the Whiskers! Even the gold players never make it worth a gentleman's while to snuff their candles. I wish the Parliament would put down all sneaking games!—A man can neither win or lose a fortune with any degree of credit at them. No—Pharo, Pharo's the sport.

SP.SPEAKER: James.
SP.P: Is this a Pharaoh's table, Mr. Forward?

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: No; but set that in the center, in the best place in the room. That's a Macao-table, and ome of the birds, I fancy, will be picked pretty bare that play at it—Five pound five.—Do you hear, James? The moment the company's gone, pack up all the cards and candles, whether used or not, and carry them to my room:—I may have occasion for them, if I should see company while I am out of place.

SP.SPEAKER: James.
SP.P: What, you leave us a few packs to make merry with in the Servants Hall, Mr. Forward? I likes a game at All ours, dealy.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Why, servants should have their amuse∣ments, as well as their betters, James; so you may strip the Whist-tables for your own use. The Dons always take snuff, and fully their cards confound∣edly.

SP.SPEAKER: James.
SP.P: Thank. you, thank you, Mr. Forward! Must I carry up the candles to your room that mayn't be lighted?

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Certainly; the others will only serve for my bed-chamber, or to dress by. I detest tallow.

SP.SPEAKER: James.
SP.P: Well, well, I'll do as I'm bid.— (aside) What a thief it is! and as great a Jew to a poor fellow-servant, as if he was not the same flesh and blood!

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: I shall make about twelve pieces pack∣ing penny. I wish my master may win to-night, as I shall call upon him for my wages to-morrow: and, to do him justice, he is always ready to pay, when he has it. The Funds are low at present, and a prudent man should not suffer his money to lie dead, especially in such hands where it may be buried, too.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady MARY and Mr. WOODLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Let the ices be brought before eleven, Forward, as I wish the assembly to break up early. Are the bouquets come from the King's Road? Let there be a profusion of rofes in all the rooms: they are delicious, at this ason.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: Your Ladyship shall be obeyed— (aside) for the last time by your Ladyship's most humble.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Your indifference upon this occasion really amazes me, Mr. Woodley! I thought you loved your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I do, most tenderly, and shall therefore rejoice at seeing her under the protection of a wor∣thy man.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Bless me! is there nothing but worth to be considred, in matrimony? no allowance to be made for liking? I vow, if you had been fifty times as worthy as you are, I would never have married you, if you had not been agreeable, also.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Sweet flatterer!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: But as the match is not to take place, his being agreeable or not is of no consequence, now.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I don't comprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You don't choose to comprehend me, Mr. Woodley. But still I must say, that the indig∣nity of Sir William's presuming to dispose of your sister without your consent, is not to be endured.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: You are misinformed, my dear. Mount∣fort asked my consent, before he applied to Sir Wil∣liam—I did not see you since.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Mountfort is quite out of the present question, I tell you, Mr. Woodley.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: You rave, my dear!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: One of us does, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I am not mad, yet, Madam—though I have enough to make me so.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: This is too much, Mr. Woodley. Every one takes notice of your behaviour to me, of late; and wonder how I bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: (looking gravely at her) Did you know what I bear—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: From me, Mr. Woodley?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Not from, but for, you, Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You terrify me! Explain your mean∣ing, I intereat you.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: It will too soon cease to be a mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Then, do not let me be the last to know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Could every pang I now endure, be doubled to save you from the shock which you must feel, I'd bear them all, without complaining. But ruin comes on apace! and that you must share it ag∣gravates my distress.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Ungenerous Woodley! to think I would shrink from any misery that attends on you! But speak your meaning clearly—suspence is tor∣ture—what misery awaits us?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Our fortune's gone, my Mary!—We are undone!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Gone! Not all—my jointure still is left.—Dispose of that, and let me go into retirement with you. With pleasure I'll renounce all the fan∣tastic gaieties of life, and find true happiness in your society.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley
SP.P: Your nobleness of mind but adds to my distress.—Your jointure! No, I will live a beggar, all my days, rather than leave you one, when I must leave you. Somewhat may yet be done to save us from destruction. I have a dependence on Mr. Bromley's friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: So have I;—but we must be our own friends, my dear.—I will go into Dorsetshire, imme∣diately. Let us discharge hal our servants, and become patterns of oeconomy and conjugal happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Generous, charming woman! Happi∣ness must attend you, every where.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: 'Tis the inseparable companion of an upright heart; and my dear Woodley shall soon be convinced from my conduct, that chearfulness can survive gaiety, and true love make ample amends for the loss of fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Your sense and virtue have removed the heaviest weight that hung upon my hear.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Then clear your brow, my dar, and let us act the last scene of the farce with the same spirit as the first.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Colonel Mountfort, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Shew him into my dressing-room—I'll wait on him instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Don't let even Colonel Mountfort perceive your dejection, my dear Woodley. We should, in kindness to our friends, conceal our sor∣rows.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: If Mountfort has succeeded with my uncle, Louisa's happiness will lighten my distress.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I have not time to ask an explanation of this matter, now.—But let me again intreat you to be chearful:—something tells me that our situa∣tion is not so bad as you imagine. Let us not anti∣cipate misfortune:—'tis always too soon to be wretched.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I will exert my utmost power, my dear, to emulate your fortitude.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P:
My fortitude! Ah Woodley! little dost thou know the perturbation here.—Ruin comes on apace!—The shock was sudden and severe; but 'twas my love, not resolution, bore me through it.—And now let me collect myself a little, and try, by Reason's standard, the value of those joys which I resign.—Dress! Won't my little person look as well in a plain silk, as in all this finery? Vanity says, Yes.—Grandeur—what is it? A magnificent side-board, a train of useless servants, gay furniture, crouded rooms, and blazing lights, which but oppress the spirits, without affording enjoyment. Elegance is not confined to state: her handmaid Neatness shall preside at our board, and render our rural fare de∣licious.—Operas! Ranelagh! Plays! Masquerades! Assemblies! Company! ay, there's the rub! So∣ciety! dear Society! I shall not find, a Mrs. Brom∣ley in Dorsetshire; but I shall have my Woodley there, and my endeavours not to let him see I grieve,
will soon make me cease to do so. My resolution's fixed—I'll acquaint Louisa with it instantly,
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Mr. WOODLEY's Dressing-room.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Upon my honour, Colonel, I am as unable to fathom Sir William's meaning, as you can be. I am certain that no person ever proposed to me for Louisa, but yourself, and she could not possibly give her consent, before it was asked.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: This assurance has revived my hopes a little; but 'tis impossible my heart can be at ease, till your sister has pronounced my doom.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: If she consults her own heart, Mount∣fort, you will not, I fancy, have much reason to com∣plain of her sentence. But as she is the only Oedi∣pus that can expound this riddle, let us apply to her for the explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: You prevent my wishes, for you have an undoubted right to make the enquiry.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Tell my sister I desire to speak with her, immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: How my heart throbs, at her ap∣proach!

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: For shame, my gallant friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: O Woodley! when all one's happiness is staked on the turn of a die, who would not trem∣ble when he stood the cast?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Miss Woodley, Sir, has just sent to let Sir William know she wishes to pay her respects to him:—at her return she will wait upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Inhuman girl! She trifles with my anxiety—perhaps rejoices in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Lovers are of all beings the most irra∣tiona. I'd hazard my life that Louisa has never heard of your proposal to Sir William, and of course can know nothing of your anxiety.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: She will be soon acquainted with both. But have not you informed her?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: No, on my honour; I have not seen her since you left me.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Your coolness on this subject, Mr. Woodley, by no means accords with my impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: You wrong me, Mountfort. Be assur∣ed, that your union with Louisa is an object my heart is set on; but that heart is torn to pieces, at present.—I cannot speak—Louisa never stays long with her uncle—she will return in a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: They will be years to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Let us meet her then, before she goes into the drawing-room.
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM's Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Poor child! I am very sorry she is coming—I know not what excuse to make for Bel∣ford—I fear it will be a grievous disappointment to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I come, Sir, most joyfully to tell you something that I am sure will give you pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William,
SP.P: My poor dear! and I have some∣thing to tell you, that I am sure will give you pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I am so much rejoiced at present, that there are but very few things that could render me unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: So much the worse—the shock will be the greater! I shall never have the courage to tell her.—The suddenness of this event, Louisa—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Do you know it, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Ay, but too well, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You quite surprise me, Sir! It is not above five minutes, since it was determined.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Yes, yes, 'tis more than that—above half an hour. But though matters have taken an unexpected turn, I would not have you fret, or grieve, child!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: So far from it, Sir, that I am quite re∣joiced, and flattered myself that you would be so too, as I know it is a point you have long set your heart upon;—and I must do Lady Mary the justice to de∣clare the plan was intirely her own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Lady Mary! I guessed as much.—How did she dare to thwart my schemes?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Dear Sir, have you not always wished that my brother and sister should live in Dorsetshire? and now that Lady Mary has, of her own accord, determined to quit London, you seem offended.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Softly, softly, child; don't hurry me!—For once in my life, I perceive I am left behind.— (aside) So, I find she knows nothing of Belford, and that work is all to do, yet.—Go on, my dear! Lady Mary, you say—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Has, unsolicited by any one, resolved to give up all the gaiety and dissipation of this town, and remain in Dorsetshire till my brother's affairs are intirely retrieved.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: She'll not return in a hurry, then, I doubt.—I am glad of it, my dear, for your sake, as well as your brother's:—air and exercise will be of great use to you.— (aside) I'm afraid she'll stand in need of them, when she is acquainted with her mis∣fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: But, my good, dear uncle, won't you give Lady Mary credit for her prudence? and won't you permit my brother and sister to take leave of you, before they go?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: I hate all forms and ceremonies, child!—They have had my leave to go into the coun∣try, these three years past; and I am less displeased with your sister, for her prudent resolution. And so, at your request, my dear, you may all breakfast with me before you set out to-morrow.— (aside) I'll defer acquainting her till then, with Belford's be∣haviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I don't believe, Sir, that they can set out so immediately; but I am certain they will not defer a moment to accept your kind invitation, on that account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Stop, child, stop! I won't have them come to me, till the very hour they are going. If I were to see your brother often, I might be weak enough to grow fond of him again; so don't let him come, I charge you, 'till his boots are on. I have trouble enough on my hands for others, al∣ready. You don't know what I suffer on your ac∣count, Louisa, at this moment. But you shall know all about it, when you are setting off for Dorset∣shire.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I wish I dare venture to make the good man's mind easy, with regard to me.—As I am perfectly resigned to your commands, Sir, on every occasion, I hope I shall never give you cause for any real trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: There now, she'll break my heart with her mildness!—I hope for your own sake you'll be resigned, my dear. But go, child, and tell your brother and Lady Mary, that I shall be glad to see them on the morning they are setting out; but not before, upon any account whatever.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I rejoice to be the messenger of such glad tidings; for if he sees my brother, I am certain he will serve him.
SP.STAGE: SCENE, a Drawing-room. Card-tables, with Com∣pany at Play.
Lady MARY, LOUISA, Mr. BELFORD, Colonel MOUNTFORT.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Whist.
SP.P: Fifty pieces on the rubber!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Whist.
SP.P: A bet, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: A Pam flush!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: You seldom deal, I think, without one, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: My Pam box can best answer that hint, Madam; for this is the first guinea I have been able to put into it, this whole winter.—But you lose, at present, Madam, and therefore have leave to speak.—Please to mark the Loo, Madam—'tis just sixty guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: How much am 'I obliged to you, my excellent friend, for so generously saving me from the pain of offending the best of uncles!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: And let me join my gratitude, Sir, for your having so kindly removed, I hope, the only obstacle to my happiness, by releasing Sir William from his promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: I heartily wish he may be inclined to transfer his favour to you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: My dear cousin, here's a place for you! The Monsters must come in with Mrs. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I'll wait upon you, in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: The Monsters positively shall not come in, 'till 'tis a single stake;—and then I shall never have a flush after, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: My dear Bromley, I have a thousand things to say to you of the utmost importance. I wish you would not play, to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P:
Not play! you must excuse me, indeed, Lady Mary! Besides, we shall have time
enough to talk over those same important matters, you know, at the Masquerade.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I shall not go, to-night, and have something so interesting to tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible she should suspect any thing.—Your Ladyship knows I hate melancholy stories.— (to the Table) Is the Loo over?— (aside) I can't help feeling a little aukward, when I speak to her.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Loo.
SP.P: Another flush, as I live! I don't be∣lieve we shall have a single stake, these two hours.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Quadrille.
SP.P: Your Ladyship's basted—you trumpted the King of Diamonds.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Quadrille.
SP.P: What then, Madam? Here take the Diamond, I have my game without it.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Quadrille.
SP.P: No, Madam—a renounce is a Beast.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Quadrille.
SP.P: I won't submit to it.—Judgment! Several. Your Ladyship's a Beast! a Beast!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: What a racket they make, at this pal∣try play! Not above a crown a-fish, I dare swear!—The Loo is just two hundred and forty guineas!—Deal, Madam.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mr. WOODLEY, and joins LOUISA.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Not keep your promise, Bromley?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Why, no, indeed, Madam! I cannot possibly think of rusticating myself with your Ladyship;—but if any of the summer camps should happen to lie near you, I may give you a call, en passant, to see how love and a cottage agree with you.—Will you never let me in, Mrs. Henpeck?

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Loo.
SP.P: Dear Madam, I wish you had been in my place, the whole evening, with all my heart! I have lost near three hundred pounds in it.—Heigh∣ho!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P:
I had vainly flattered myself, it seems, that my company might have rendered the country
passable, at least, to one who professed herself my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I always thought your Ladyship very romantic.— (aside) I wish she would not teaze me so!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: This shock is much severer to me, than the first I felt, as friends were dearer to me than fortune.—But let me rise above her worthlessness, nor let her see how her unkindness wounds me.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Whist.
SP.P: Lurched at four! 'tis confounded hard!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Whist.
SP.P: I bet you three to one.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: — (to Mrs. Bromley) Will Mr. Bromley be here, to-night?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Certainly.—Sooner than you wish, I fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Pray, Mrs. Bromley, did you hire those ear-rings from my jeweller? I'm glad now, he did not alter them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I have never yet been under the necessity of hiring jewels, Madam, whatever other people may have been. But though the setting of these is not altered, Madam, the property is;—for they are mine, at present, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: You'll pardon me, Mrs. Bromley.—Mr. Woodley, pray are not those my ear-rings?

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: They were, my dear.— (aside) This is ungenerous of Bromley!—I will explain this mat∣ter another time, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Woodley, it requires but little explanation. Lady Mary is not so much a child as not to know, that, in this country, and in these times, property quickly changes hands, from those who have squandered their own fortunes, and possibly that of others, to those who have been more prudent, and less lavish.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Loo.
SP.P: The Loo is over, Mrs. Bromley.—Bring the Monsters, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I thought it would never be a single stake!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Her unkindness would be in∣supportable, did not the insolence of it render her despicable.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Don't you think, Miss Woodley, that Lady Mary looks uncommonly grave, this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You will not be surprised at her serious∣ness, when I tell you that she has determined on quitting London immediately, and retiring with my brother into Dorsetshire. I shall go with them, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: And I shall as certainly follow my leader. Sir William can have no objection to my being can∣toned in the neighbourhood of Woodley Park, I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Whist.
SP.P: Four by honours, again! This is the fourth time you have dealt them, in the rubber. Six∣teen out of twenty, are odds that Demoivre could not play against.—There's your money, there's your money, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Whist.
SP.P: No—double or quit with your Lord∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Whist.
SP.P: I know I am a bubble, but I hate to cut a loser.—'Tis a bet, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: Two Pams, as I hope to be saved!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Fie, Madam, don't swear! 'tis vastly ill-bred.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: 'Tis much worse breeding to cheat, Mrs. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: Mean creature! I scorn your words.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: You should begin by scorning mean actions, Madam. But you shan't take up the Loo, I assure you—I have long suspected you of such tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: And so have I.—Heigh-ho!—she has got a deal of my money.—Heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Loo.
SP.P: And of mine too, I assure you;—but her surprising luck is now clearly accounted for.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: I won't touch another card with such vulgar, suspicious wretches.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: We have renounced you first, Madam;—so if you please to rise from the table, Madam, and I'll take care that you shall never sit down to any other where-ever I am present, I assure you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: Put all the Monsters out, at once.—Heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.STAGE: (rising in a passion, and addressing Lady Mary)
SP.P: I did not think your Ladyship would stand tamely by, and suffer me to be insulted in your house; but 'tis the last time I shall ever come into it, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: I shall take care that you shan't break that promise, if you shou'd happen to forget it, Mrs. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bromley.
SP.P: You speak like an oracle, with∣out consciousness, Madam; for this is the last night you will ever have any authority here, believe me: and so I leave your Ladyship to your future rural felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Was there ever so sudden and extraordinary a change in any human creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: 'Tis rather a discovery, than a metamor∣phose, my dear Lady Mary!—I have long seen through Mrs. Bromley's mask—'twas only made of gauze.
SP.STAGE: Enter FORWARD, and speaks to Mr. WOODLEY.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: There are some Gentlemen below, Sir, who, though not invited, insist upon coming up.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Admit them, directly—all Gentlemen are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: I should have done so, Sir, but that these Gentlemen don't seem to be well enough dressed for my Lady's assembly—They are but Bailiffs, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Distraction! my disgrace is public, now!

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: At whose suit do they come here?

SP.SPEAKER: Forward.
SP.P: I think they mentioned Mr. Bromley, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: Impossible! he is the very friend I thought of applying to, in my present difficulties.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Don't be too confident, Mr. Woodley. I know that fellow to be a consummate knave.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Don't let your spirits sink, my dear Woodley.—We'll inquire into the matter, and ac∣commodate it immediately.—I beg your Ladyship not to be alarmed—every thing shall be settled, directly. Try to support your sister's sinking heart, my dear Louisa.
SP.STAGE: [Louisa seems to comfort Lady Mary, who is in Tears, and both go out together.]

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Whist.
SP.P: Bailiffs, did the fellow say? Egad, I'll decamp in time.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Whist.
SP.P: You must not stir, 'till the rubber is out, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Whist.
SP.P: Your Lordship must excuse me!—Such incidents are so common, to be sure, in the present times, that they cease to be scandalous; but that does not prevent my being affected by them. I shall re∣member that seven to four are the points of our game, and for debts of honour, my Lord, you'll always find me solvent.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Whist.
SP.P:
These scenes are apt to affect me, too, Charles!—I never could stand them.—Peers are pri∣vileged from such sympathies; so let us counter∣march
down the back-stairs, together, or we may be lurched, though we are seven.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: I shall faint, if I see them!—I must go, Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: Let us have another round, Madam! We are all married women, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: My antipathy to these harpies was con∣tracted while I was a widow, Madam.—'Tis your deal, Madam—Poor Lady Mary!—Heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: Ay, poor Lady Mary, I say too;—tho' to be sure, one cannot have any great compassion for such an extravagant woman.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Loo.
SP.P: Compassion! No, truly!—Such suppers after her routs! though I was never asked to one of them. That cheat Bromley was one of her chief favourites, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: She is gone out of the room, as I live, without making the least apology.—Did you ever hear of such rudeness! I'll never visit her again.—Heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: Nor I.—'Tis time to break up, indeed, when the Lady of the house has retired!—I'll carry off this Pam, to triumph over that rude wretch, Bromley. I shall have the honour of seeing you all, to-morrow night.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: My coach was not ordered 'till twelve.—Will you carry me to Lady Freakish's rout? They never meet there, 'till eleven.

SP.SPEAKER: 3d Loo.
SP.P: With pleasure.—But I insist upon telling the story of the Woodleys.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Loo.
SP.P: And I of Mrs. Bromley.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Loo.
SP.P: Then I have nothing left to do, but to count my losses.—Heigh-ho!
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM'S Apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Why didn't you say I was gone to bed? She'll break my rest, for this night, at least. She has heard of her misfortune, I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: sir William.
SP.P: Yes, yes, 'tis all out, now.—Nay, my dear child, don't take on so—you'll break my heart, if you do.—'I was not my sault, Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Don't talk or think of faults, now, Sir.—You know that before this disgraceful event happen∣ed in the family—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Don't you talk of it in such a me∣lancholy strain, child;—'tis no disgrace, I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: 'Tis too public to be concealed, Sir. The Bailiffs are but this moment gone out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: What house? This house? Your brother's house? What! have they carried him to prison? I thought it would come to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No, Sir—Colonel Mountfort gene∣rously—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: What had he to do with it? Why should olonel Mountfort, or any one else? Why didn't they send to me?—But what have I to do wih your brother, child? He should have gone to prion.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: He would not long have languished there, Sir believe me; a broken heart would soon have rlased him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Psha, psha—with your broken heart—You play the fool with me!—My nephew pe∣rish in a ga! But he has brought it all on himself, you know, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I grant that his imprudence, Sir, has ex∣ceeded every thing, but your good-nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Confound my good-nature! it is for ever bringing me into scrapes—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: And bringing others out of them, my dear uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Well, well, well—I want Belford, now, extremely!—Every thing falls out unlucky!—But what of Colonel Mountfort, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I was going to tell you, Sir, that he be∣came security for my brother, on the instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: That's noble! for he did not know that I would discharge the debt.—Nay, for that mat∣ter, I don't know that I shall—I promise nothing—but I like this action of the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I rejoice to hear it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Ay! then perhaps you like the Co∣lonel? Be honest, speak out.—I should be glad to make you some amends for a loss you don't yet know of;—but I can conceal it no longer.—Belsord has declared off!—but he is unworthy your resentment. The Colonel's father was my friend, and a noble fellow he was!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: And his son is every way worthy of such a father!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: (aside) I rejoice to find her so easily reconciled.—Well, that matter is settled, for the present.—But are you certain that your brother and Lady Mary will hold their resolution of retiring to Dorsetshire?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You know, Sir, it was their determined purpose, before this misfortune happened.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P:
That's something in their favour, to be sure, and I'm glad you told me of it.—One good act of choice, is worth all the virtues of necessity, in the world.—I should be glad to make their minds easy, to-night—But they'd thank me, and talk to me, and discompose me, and I should lose my night's rest—for I hate thanks.—I should be glad to see Co∣lonel
Mountfort:—his behaviour has shewn a respect to me, and the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: You will meet him now, at my brother's, Sir, where your presence will make them all happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Well, child, I can deny you no∣thing.—I like to make people happy, when they'll assist me in doing so, themselves; without which the best endeavours are but labour in vain.—But the country is the place!—You must settle in the coun∣try, Louisa!—There is no safety for good folks in London, believe me, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I should hope, Sir, that with prudence and virtue one might be safe any where.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: A fig for your prudence—ay, and for virtue too, against example! Example, child, is the ruin of us all. We naturally strive to ape those that are called our Betters, and so become worse than we otherwise should be.—But this is no time for mo∣ralizing. Do you step in and tell your brother I am coming. I'll just wrap my cloak round me and follow you.
SP.STAGE: SCENE changes to Mr. WOODLEY's Dressing-room.
Mr. WOODLEY, Mr. BELFORD, and Colonel MOUNTFORT.

SP.SPEAKER: Belford.
SP.P: Fear not, my gallant Colonel! Mr. Woodley shall have ample vengeance upon that scoundrel Bromley; for as he has evidently altered the date of the bond, we shall find a way to reward his ingenuity.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: I know not whether I am most astonish∣ed at his villany, or at my own weakness in being duped by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: The uprightness of your own heart, my dear Woodley, is the best excuse for your credulity.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I come the happy messenger of joyful tidings! My dear good uncle—But he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: I'm glad to meet you here, all to∣gether, for I have business with every one of you, jointly and severally.—And first for you, Colonel, I am very much obliged to you, Sir, and I scorn to be obliged to any man, without making him some return for his kindness. I therefore make you a pre∣sent I refused you, a few hours ago, for the sake of old Sir Doubtful Deliberation there.—But do you take Louisa, and for aught I know, you may make her as good a husband as he would have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I shall use my best endeavours, Sir, to deserve—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: That's right—stick to that.—No thanks, but deserve as much as ever you can.—And as for you, Mr. Belford, though I am confoundedly angry with you, I must get you to settle this young man's affairs; his debts of honour, his post obits, &c.; though perhaps it may be only affording him an opportunity for deranging them again.—That's the modern phrase, I think, for being over-head-and-ears in debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Woodley.
SP.P: The sufferings my follies have brought upon me, Sir, and the remembrance of your gene∣rosity, will remain too strongly impressed on my mind, to admit of my relapsing into my former errors; as that would be adding ingratitude to ex∣travagance, and vice to folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P:
Well, well, I hope so.—Kindness should be the strongest tie to a generous mind, and I suspect you not of any baseness in your nature;—though, to be sure, you have shewn a plentiful lack of wisdom in your conduct. But misfortunes
make Solomons of us all!—And now, Madam, (to Lady Mary) to shew you that the merit of your vo∣luntary retirement into the country, is not lost upon me, I make you a present of this house, for your winter residence.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Your kindness, Sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: Stop there—I won't be thanked—I wish to do as I would be done by; and as I should not like to be confined in the finest place in the world, not even Woodley Park, I would not impose such a restraint on one who I doubt not will hereafter merit my indulgence.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: Gratitude overwhelms me, Sir!—I cannot speak my sense of your goodness as it deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir William.
SP.P: So much the better!—There are nobler ways of shewing one's sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Mary.
SP.P: They shall be demonstrated in my future conduct, Sir; for the virtue that arises from the conviction of past errors, must be at once sincere, and permanent.
